results.title: This Day Tonight: The 1967 Referendum
results.brief_description:
Traditionally Australian people have voted ‘No’ to changes to the Constitution. What made the 1967 Referendum so historically significant is the resounding approval of two amendments intended to benefit Australia’s Indigenous population.
This section of the Referendum was broken up into two parts, the first concerning what was called the ‘race powers’ of the Federal Government, allowing them to create laws to specifically benefit Indigenous people. The second was to delete the part of the constitution that stated that Aboriginal natives should not be counted when tallying the population, more directly affecting representation in parliament and the allocation of Commonwealth grants.
These amendments were passed with an overall ‘Yes’ vote of over 90%.
‘This Day Tonight’ focuses on certain pockets of the community who had overall voted ‘No’ to this part of the Referendum. This provides a glimpse of some of the prevailing attitudes of the time regarding the Indigenous population. The Referendum is set against a background of increased awareness of Aboriginal issues and amid demands by the Indigenous population for equal rights and recognition. The issues regarding improving living conditions for Aboriginal Australians is also discussed and considered.
The second part of the Referendum that was rejected by the Australian people was pertaining to what was called the ‘Nexus’, that would essentially link the number of representatives in each house of the Australian Federal Parliament. In looking at how people voted on the ‘Nexus’ issue, again a range of opinions were covered, providing an insight to attitudes towards politicians as well as why the amendment was rejected.
Also included in this program are the results of a student survey conducted by Swinburne Institute of Technology and some of the highlights of the 14th Annual Sydney Film Festival.

results.title: Catalyst: Fire Storm
results.creator_credit: Andrew Holland, Ian Cuming and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
A scientific investigation into the causes of the catastrophic Canberra bushfires of January 2003 where 474 homes were destroyed and four lives lost. Includes interviews with residents, scientists, environmentalists and fire-fighters.
Episode from the ABC TV series ‘Catalyst’ presented and narrated by Karina Kelly.

results.title: Channel Seven Sport : Up There Cazaly [advertisement]
results.brief_description:
A television commercial for Channel Seven Sport’s coverage of Australian Rules Football, using the song ‘Up There Cazaly’ written by Mike Brady and Peter Sullivan. The song was inspired by the high flying marks of Roy Cazaly who played during the 1920s. The commercial shows some spectacular high marks and bruising bumps.
Produced by Campaign Palace.

results.title: Guess whose mum's got a Whirlpool [advertisement]
results.brief_description: Dame Edna Everage, the housewife superstar, introduces us to the new compact washer and also the now famous tag line, ‘guess whose mum’s got a Whirlpool’.

results.title: Australian tourism [advertisement]
results.brief_description: Developed by Mojo MDA for the Australian Tourism Commission this advertisement was part of the ‘come and say g’day’ campaign and features Paul Hogan in a range of locations across Australia. It also uses a range of Australian slang expressions including a play on the famous expression ‘put another prawn on the barbie’.

results.title: Meeting of minds: the mentor program
results.creator_credit: Ivan Gaal and Victoria. Ministry of Education
results.brief_description: This program explores four mentor-student relationships. Each relationship is unique and serves to demonstrate the versatility of the mentor concept. The students are shown in their home and school environment. Administrative processes involved in the mentor program are also illustrated.

results.title: The Age of change
results.creator_credit: Ivan Gaal and Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description: Looks at the impact of technological change on the Melbourne newspaper ‘The Age’ and considers this change in terms of its effect on the people involved. Highlights the increasing competition at the desk of reporters and editors from electronic information systems, and the impact of technology on the once labour-intensive area of printing.

results.title: Celebrations
results.creator_credit: Ivan Gaal and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre
results.brief_description: A documentary film presenting six different and authentic celebrations involving people in the multicultural community of Melbourne. Depicts an Aboriginal dance showing body decoration preparation, an Indonesian Muslim wedding celebration, an Australian child’s birthday party, a Greek nameday party, Christmas festivities and a Northern Italian Christmas celebration. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Getting the message
results.creator_credit: Ivan Gaal and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre
results.brief_description: Dramatization of the difficulties faced by an illiterate adult in employment and social situations. Suggests that with concern and adequate teaching methods this problem can be overcome. The film highlights the plight of the hundreds of illiterate Australian adults.

results.title: The Punter
results.brief_description: A short film about Jack Burnett and his involvment in the horse racing industry in the 1970s. (Jack is the father-in-law of the filmmaker) Identifiable with many students. Could be used for discussion on the idea of bought leisure and deals with gambling relating to horse racing.
